There are so many ways of counting because the Democratic process of delegate allocation is so complicated.
But the Associated Press, which is our standard, says that so far Clinton has a thousand delegates, Obama has 902.
That's counting superdelegates, the elected officials and party bigwigs who are not pledged or committed.
So that puts Obama within the magic number of a hundred that most people would consider striking distance of Clinton.
And I think you have to say that by any measure, Clinton did not dominate yesterday.
Not by delegates, not by states, or by the popular vote.
They each got about 7.3 million votes.
They were only about one-third of 1 percentage point apart.
And here is what Barack Obama had to say today about how he did yesterday.
The Clinton camp's basic attitude was that the whole calendar was set up to deliver the knock-out blow on February 5th.
And not only did we play them to a draw, we won more delegates and we won more states.

According to the Associated Press, John McCain now has almost 60 percent of what he needs to clinch the nomination.
He has about 703 delegates; Mitt Romney has 260; Mike Huckabee has 190.
So McCain has more than twice what Romney has, more than three times what Huckabee has.
It's interesting though, McCain got only 3 and a half million votes yesterday.
So the entire Republican field got only about 500,000 more votes than either Obama or Clinton.
So you can see how turnout is really favoring the Democrats.
But John McCain still has a lot of issues to resolve within his own party.
He is in the driver's seat.
It's hard to see a path for Romney or Huckabee.
But tomorrow, you're going to see Romney try to find a path.

I just want to clarify something.

It's not mathematically impossible but Romney would have to run the table.
He will have to win absolutely everything else.
And that seems impossible if not mathematically impossible.

Thank you, Mara.
That was NPR national political correspondent Mara Liasson.
Mikayla Sharrieff, India Skinner and Bria Snell should only be proud this week.

The 17-year-old women, all juniors at Benjamin Banneker High School in Washington, D.C., created a simple way to use copper shards, drinking straws and filter flaws - simple, though I'm not smart enough to understand it - to show how to purify water in school drinking fountains that may be contaminated by lead.
They tested and even tasted the water.
Their rudimentary purifier works.
The three friends became one of eight teams that are finalists in a NASA competition to apply space technologies to earthly challenges.
They invited people to vote for projects on social media platforms.
The water purifier devised by the young women seemed to win attention.
Hundreds of schools across the United States have drinking water that is contaminated by lead.
It's a serious problem that could use good ideas.
And by the way, the students from Banneker are the only team among the finalists who are all African-American women.

At a time when they should have heard nothing but accolades and encouragement, some unidentified people on 4chan, an Internet posting site where racists and homophobes have posted anonymous nonsense, began to put up bigoted comments about the young women.
There's no need to quote those comments here.
The trolls suggested ways to hack the NASA voting system to prevent the young women from winning.
NASA decided they had to shut down the voting system because it was compromised.
They denounced the racist attacks and added, NASA continues to support outreach and education for all Americans, and encourages all of our children to reach for the stars.
India Skinner told the Washington Post she hopes people would see photos of their team and see we're just regular girls and we want to be scientists.
The winners will spend two days at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland.
As to their futures, Ms. Skinner would like to become a pediatric surgeon.
Ms. Sharrieff plans to become a biomedical engineer.
Ms. Snell would like to be an anesthesiologist.
I cannot imagine what the kinds of people who post racial insults about promising young students might wind up doing with their lives.
The three young women from Banneker High School seem to be well on their way to helping others.

Coming up, the tangled world of octopus romance.
First though, to a cold war match that has only recently come to light.
It is, it was between the U.S, and Taiwan.
The story was buried and recently declassified intelligence information.
It's about the Black Bats.
A group of Taiwanese pilots that ran dangerous intelligence missions against Mainland China with the help of the CIA.
AS NPR's Anthony Kuhn reports from Taiwan, the Black Bats were covert warriors in a forgotten war.
The story of the Black Bats came out through the Taiwanese media.
And this documentary by Hong Kong's Phoenix television.
In the early 1950's on Taiwan, Chiang Kai-shek was looking for ways to retake Mainland China which he had lost to the Communists in 1949.
The U.S.
meanwhile was battling China in the Korean War.
That's me, says Colonel Lee Chiong-Chan pointing to a picture of himself in front of a Boeing B17 bomber.
I was an electronic counter measures officer, he says.
Colonel Lee guides me through a military museum in Hsinchu near the Black Bats' old air base.
Preparations are underway to open a new museum devoted solely to the Black Bats.
Colonel Lee says the Bats painted their planes black and flew only at night.
(Through Translator) We could pick up anything transmitted by electronic waves he says.
From this, we could probe their air defenses and figure out how their military was deployed.
The Black Bats' pilots dropped pamphlets encouraging communist pilots to defect.
They parachuted spies and saboteurs onto the mainland, few of whom ever made it back.
Pilot Dai Shu-Chin(ph) recalls how he relied on skill and guts to accomplish his missions.
(Through Translator) Most of their anti-aircraft guns were deployed along the coast.
I would fly in 100 feet off the ground.
By the time their guns open fire, they were too late and I was in.
As Mainland Chinese air defenses improved, they shutdown more of the Black Bats.
The Bats flew a total of more than 800 missions but they lost two-thirds of their pilots in the process.
Pilot Ju Jin(ph) remembers one close call.
(Through Translator) One enemy plane in front of me would drop flares.
Another plane in the back saw me.
Their jets were faster.
All I could do was dodge.
I turned hard and saw the plane behind me firing at my silhouette.
I only escaped because he used up all his ammunition.
(Soundbite of aircraft)
The Black Bats were joined by the Black Cats who flew U-2 spy planes over China.
Both groups were instrumental in gathering information about China's nuclear weapons program in the mid 1960s.
When the pilots returned to base, they turned over their intelligence to Western Enterprises, Inc., a front for the CIA.
Western Enterprises equipped and trained the Taiwanese pilots and designed their missions.
James Lilley was a CIA case officer in Taiwan during the 1950's and the ambassador to China in the 1980's.
He explains about Western Enterprises.
